abstract.text: The high abundance of (anti-)deuterons in the statistics gathered in Run 1 of the LHC and the excellent performance of the ALICE setup allow for the simultaneous measurement of the elliptic flow and the deuteron production rates with a large transverse momentum (p T ) reach. The (anti-) deuterons are identified using the specific energy loss in the time projection chamber and the velocity information in the time-of-flight detector. The elliptic flow of (anti-)deuterons can provide insight into the production mechanisms of particles in heavy-ion collisions. Quark coalescence is one of the approaches to describe the elliptic flow of hadrons, while the production of light nuclei can be also depicted as a coalescence of nucleons. In these proceedings, the measured v 2 of deuterons produced in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV will be compared to expectations from coalescence and hydrodynamic models.

body_text.text: Introduction

Anisotropic flow [1] studies can probe the nature of matter produced in heavy-ion collisions. These studies allow for the investigation of collective effects among produced particles. The angular distribution of all the reconstructed charged particles can be expanded into a Fourier series w.r.t. symmetry plane Ψ {n} :
where E is the energy of the particle, p the momentum, p T the transverse momentum, ϕ the azimuthal angle, y the rapidity, Ψ {n} the symmetry plane angle and v n = cos n(ϕ − Ψ {n} ) .

The second term of the Fourier series (v 2 ) is called elliptic flow and is a parameter which may provide insight on initial conditions and particle production mechanisms. For identified hadrons v 2 is sensitive to the partonic degrees of freedom in the early stages of the evolution of a heavy-ion collision [2]. The deuteron is a composite p+n bound state, whose binding energy (∼ 2.24 MeV) is much lower than the hadronization temperature. Thus, it is likely that it would suffer from medium induced breakup in the hadronic phase, even if it was produced at hadronization. The v 2 measurements for d and d provide an important test for the universal scaling of elliptic flow [3] since its v 2 should be additive both with respect to the v 2 of its constituent hadrons and with respect to the v 2 of the constituent quarks of these hadrons, i.e. n q = 2 × 3. In these proceedings, the measurements of (anti-)deuterons v 2 are compared to other identified particles [4] and to a model based on hydrodynamics [5,6].
Analysis Details

For the analyses presented here, a sample of about 35 million Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV collected by ALICE [7] in 2011 were used. The events were classified into 6 different centrality intervals, which were determined using the forward V0 [8] scintillator arrays. Particle tracking is done by means of the Time Projection Chamber (TPC) [9] and the Inner Tracking System (ITS) [10] with full azimuthal coverage for |η| <0.8. The identification of deuteron (d) and anti-deuteron (d) was performed in the same way as done to extract deuteron spectra in Pb-Pb [11]. Specifically, for momenta up to 1 GeV/c the energy loss in the TPC gives a clean sample of (anti-)deuterons by requiring a maximum deviation of the specific energy loss of 3σ with respect to the expected signal. Above 1 GeV/c a Time of Fight (TOF) [7] hit is required. The signal in the TOF detector is fitted with a function which is the sum of a Gaussian with an exponential tail, while the background is fitted with an exponential. As an example of the ∆M, where ∆M = m TOF -m d PDG , for deuterons and anti-deuterons with 2.20 < p T < 2.40 GeV/c and centrality interval 30-40% is shown in the left part of Figure 1. The v 2 was measured using the Scalar Product (SP) method [12]. The contribution to the measured elliptic flow (v 2 Tot ) due to misidentified deuterons (v 2 Bkg ) was removed by studying the azimuthal correlations versus ∆M. Comparison with other identified particles

The measured (d+d) v 2 was compared with the v 2 of other identified particles [4]. Results for events with centrality in 30-40% are shown in Figure 2. In the top left panel the v 2 vs p T of π ± (empty circles), (p+p) (filled square) and (d+d) (filled circles) as a function of p T are shown. It is observed that at low p T deuterons follow the mass ordering observed for lighter particles, which is attributed to the interplay between elliptic and radial flow. The second panel in the top part of the figure shows the v 2 /A vs p T /A of (p+p) (filled squares) and (d+d) (filled circles), while in the second panel of the lower part the ratios between the measured data and a 7 th degree polynomial used to describe proton v 2 are reported. For p T /A>1 GeV/c a deviation from the p T /A scaling of the order of 20% is observed. A similar deviation is observed for all the measured centrality intervals. The third panels (upper and lower part) are used to test the n q (number of constituent quark) scaling: both p T and measured v 2 were scaled by n q . Also in this case a deviation for the n q scaling of the order of ≈20% for each centrality interval is observed. Finally, in the upper fourth panel, the measured v 2 /n q is shown as a function of EK T /n q = (m T − m 0 )/n q of each particle: significant deviations from n q scaling are seen in data for deuterons.
Comparison with Blast-Wave model

Hydrodynamical calculations are able to reproduce the main features of v 2 for p T <2 GeV/c [4]. A simple model based on hydrodynamics is the Blast-Wave model [5,6]. The measured pions, kaons and protons p T spectra and v 2 (p T ) were fitted, and the parameters of the fit were used to predict deuteron v 2 (p T ). The results for 30-40% mid-central events are shown in Figure 3. For deuterons a good description of the data in the measured p T range and for all the measured centralities is observed.
Conclusions

The v 2 of deuterons produced in Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV was measured up to 5 GeV/c using the scalar product technique. At low p T deuteron v 2 follows mass ordering, indicating a more pronounced radial flow in the most central collisions as observed also for lighter particles. A deviation from A (number of mass) and n q (number of constituent quark) scaling at the level of 20% is observed. The Blast-Wave model gives a good description of the measured elliptic flow of deuterons.
